title: Gunman Jarrod Ramos admits murdering five newspaper workers but says he's insane
text:
Gunman Jarrod Ramos has admitted killing five staff at the Capital Gazette newspaper in Annapolis, Maryland, but says he was insane at the time

A gunman who killed five workers at a newspaper in revenge for a damaging story it published about him admitted murder by reason of insanity.

Jarrod Ramos, 39, admitted killing journalists Gerald Fischman, Rob Hiaasen, John McNamara and Wendi Winters, as well as sales assistant Rebecca Smith, at the Capital Gazette newsroom in Annapolis, Maryland.

Monday’s court hearing saw him plead guilty to bursting into the office with a pump-action shotgun in June 2018 and killing all five, with the shootout leaving two further staff injured.

He plotted the massacre after the paper ran a story about him admitting a charge of harassing an old school friend in 2011.

Ramos subsequently sued the paper for defamation, but his lawsuit failed, prompting him to send a slew of threatening messages before finally launching the deadly attack.

The June 2018 massacre killed (clockwise from top left) Rob Hiaasen, Gerald Fischman, Rebecca Smith, John McNamara and Wendi Winters (Pictures: Capital Gazette)

Veteran defense attorney Peter O’Neill told the Capital Gazette that the guilty plea could be a cynical move to downplay ‘the horrific nature of the acts he committed.’

Fellow former defense attorney John Robinson explained: ‘It kind of steals (prosecutors’) presentation — the violence, the shock.’

And Baltimore defense attorney Natalie Fiknegar agreed that the guilty by way of insanity plea was ‘a very wise defense maneuver’ by Ramos’ team.

She said jurors would be less likely to feel sympathy towards Ramos’ mental health conditions after listening to prosecutors present the horrific facts of the massacre first.

His plea has not yet been formally accepted by Judge Laura Ripken.

Staff are led to safety from the Capital Gazette building after the June 2018 shooting which killed five of their colleagues (Picture: ABC)

The Capital Gazette went to print as normal the day after the attack, with its staff later awarded a Pullitzer for their ‘courageous’ response to the tragedy (Picture: Capital Gazette)

If she agrees to it, Ramos will face further court hearings to decide whether he can be held legally responsible for the killings.

State doctors with the Maryland Department of Health previously asserted that Ramos was sane when he committed the massacre.

Damning security footage showed him methodically ‘hunting’ for victims while prowling the paper’s newsroom.

Prosecutors have indicated they want to see Ramos sentenced to five life sentences without parole.

The Capital Gazette later won a Pulitzer Prize for their ‘courageous response’ to the massacre, which saw them put out a paper as usual hours after the attack on their offices.
